repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

did.abstract: Francis Murphy was a gospel temperance evangelist. Collection includes two letters, four newspaper clippings, an etching of Murphy, along with Murphy's own temperance pledge card.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Francis Murphy was a gospel temperance evangelist.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Researchers must register and agree to copyright and privacy laws before using this collection.
All or portions of this collection may be housed off-site in Duke University's Library Service Center. The library may require up to 48 hours to retrieve these materials for research use.
Please contact Research Services staff before visiting the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library to use this collection.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Francis Murphy Papers were received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a purchase in 2016.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Francis Murphy Papers, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Accessions described in this collection guide: 2016-0200

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: Collection includes two letters, four newspaper clippings, an etching of Murphy, along with Murphy's own temperance pledge card. The newspaper clippings cover Murphy's life and religious work for temperance, except one, which focuses on "Johnny Clem, the drummer boy of Shiloh." In one letter (1871 July 25), Murphy states that he is preparing notes of his visit to Hartford, and records an introduction to Mrs. O'Donivan Rosar; the second letter (1871 October 30) provides an introduction on behalf of "Brother Scott."
